channel.title: Alex Wilson's writing
channel.description: Alex on engineering, products & everything in-between

item.title: Weeknotes: Thanh — Week 11, 2025
item.description: This week was spent in Ho Chi Minh City 🇻🇳 for both a business trip, and my first trip outside of Tokyo since the big move. This week in data: 🌞 Average temperature: 31°C 🌫️ Average humidity 67.36% 🤢 Cockroaches…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This week was spent in Ho Chi Minh City 🇻🇳 for both a business trip, and my first trip outside of Tokyo since the big move.

  • This week in data:

    • 🌞 Average temperature: 31°C
    • 🌫️ Average humidity 67.36%
    • 🤢 Cockroaches spotted: 34

  • Monday begins mega early in Narita and possibly the slowest airport check in I’ve ever done. Nearly an hour. Thankfully the rest of the journey to the gate was speedy, but, reader, I’d be lying if I didn’t say that this felt mega dicey.

  • Immediately on landing I’m struck by the heat. It’s hot. It’s so hot that every minute feels like five. By the time we get to a taxi my brain has nearly adjusted.

  • Our first meal is Phở at a local place, and it ends up being one of the tastiest meals of the week as well as due to my choice of toppings probably the least healthy. We get oodles of free vegetables which - coming from Tokyo - is amazing.

  • Bikes. Bikes everywhere.

  • With many of us colocated in the same space for the first time in a while, we ran through lots of workshops ranging from talking about our backgrounds to experiencing what it’s like for users to use one of our products. Great energy all around and I enjoyed the time with people I don’t normally work with.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Searching — Week 10, 2025
item.description: Hello from Narita. I took three trains and a bus to get here — normally it’s only one train — so, not in a great mood. Hopefully tomorrow’s breakfast will make the journey worth it! With next week being my first real…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Hello from Narita. I took three trains and a bus to get here — normally it’s only one train — so, not in a great mood. Hopefully tomorrow’s breakfast will make the journey worth it!
  • With next week being my first real travel since moving to Japan, this week was all about working through a shopping list and a todo list of preparation.
  • It snowed on Tuesday! Proper snow! In March! I don’t even own snow boots anymore!
  • Prepping a workshop for next week really didn’t take long. Finding the right brand of insect spray, surprisingly, did.
  • For lack of having the ingredients, to celebrate Pancake Day I bought some premade pancakes, some honey and some sour cream. It wasn’t until too late in the process that I realised I’d made glorified doriyaki, reader, but damn were they good.
  • Still running!
  • Is it me or is there a secret second last train which doesn’t appear on the train timetable, immediately after the last train? It’s either that or I believed a bunch of ghosts.
  • The phrase “cost…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Deepening — Week 09, 2025
item.description: This was the week when I tried every single commodity LLM, and a few other things we’re labelling “AI”. And let me tell you, oh boy have my opinions on AI flip-flopped like the integrity of a career politician. More on…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This was the week when I tried every single commodity LLM, and a few other things we’re labelling “AI”. And let me tell you, oh boy have my opinions on AI flip-flopped like the integrity of a career politician. More on that after the break.

  • This week in data:

    • Papers read: 3
    • Distance run: 13.29km
    • Gigs attended: 1

  • To put it mildly, it really hasn’t been a good week from a current affairs perspective. On Thursday I started writing a message to someone and by the time I sent it on Sunday I had to redraft it, twice.

  • This has been a good week for paperwork on Planet Alex. I signed the lease for my long-term apartment this week, which was a much more involved process than any other contract signing I’ve ever done, including the ones through [name of a random previous employer]’s procurement system. 10 sheets of A3 paper. My wonderful agent even had a pen and a bottle of water ready for my troubles. If anyone is looking for property in Tokyo, I will definitely connect you, please ask.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Boxes — Week 8, 2025
item.description: Headline this week is that I moved at the weekend. Goodbye Shibaura and hello Azabu. It’s a considerably different experience: Some streets round here don't feel like Tokyo. And amongst other things, I traded a work…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Headline this week is that I moved at the weekend. Goodbye Shibaura and hello Azabu. It’s a considerably different experience: Some streets round here don't feel like Tokyo. And amongst other things, I traded a work desk for a dining table. I haven’t had a dining table since August 2021. Now my breakfasts feel somehow dignified.

  • This week in data:

    • Papers read: 0
    • Distance run: 10.82km
    • Gigs attended: 0

  • Class is going well. We formally began the Kanji. At some point I have learned to handwrite most of the katakana and hiragana. And at Tuesday lunchtime I managed to order in a non-English-speaking restaurant without any aids, and it didn’t seem very awkward.

  • Second month in a row that I’m deep-cleaning a flat. This one was a bit easier at least: Three months is a lot less than four years.

  • MA helped me move by renting a van and helping me shift 3 bags, 2 suitcases and 1 box all in one go. This was by far the easiest inter-city move I’ve ever done — the hard part was sourcing the bags — and I hope the next one goes just as smoothly.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Settling — Week 7, 2025
item.description: This was a pretty good week. I had a moment where I thought back to a question someone asked me, and I realised, that I couldn’t fault a single day this week. Considering the number of big changes that have happened in…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This was a pretty good week. I had a moment where I thought back to a question someone asked me, and I realised, that I couldn’t fault a single day this week. Considering the number of big changes that have happened in the past 12 weeks alone, that's pretty huge. This felt good in a calm way.

  • This week in data:

    • 🚶 Distance walked: 115,895 steps
    • 🧉 Jasmine tea drunk: 3 litres

  • To solve an incredibly annoying migration problem in a repeatable way, I wrote some code which parses the ES AST to extract its exports. And, it, worked? Normally I don’t do something so low-level and cursed until at least summer? So I’m pretty chuffed with that.

  • Had two stand-out work lunches, only one of which was probably unhealthy.

  • Got accepted for the apartment I applied for, which is wonderful news, but the move-in date is a little ways off. So during the week I signed another short-term lease, this one for a flat in Minami-Azabu. It’s not the most convenient for going to other parts of Tokyo, but it’s an extremely nice area I’ve always enjoyed passing through, and being just on the cusp of walkable to work, I’ll probably never again have the opportunity to stay there. I’m mega excited to explore a new neighbourhood. Move-in next weekend.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Emdashing — Week 6, 2025
item.description: Class update: Katakana are happening and they’re happening fast. I’m staying (mostly) on top of vocab, at least. Learning katakana is making grocery shopping significantly easier, mind. I finally found oatmeal, and in…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Class update: Katakana are happening and they’re happening fast. I’m staying (mostly) on top of vocab, at least.

  • Learning katakana is making grocery shopping significantly easier, mind. I finally found oatmeal, and in case the picture wasn’t enough, I know enough letters to now know that it says “OATMEAL”. So that’s neat. Lessons are already paying for themselves.

  • This week in data:

    • 🍣 Sushi consumed: 21 pieces
    • 🥣 Oatmeal consumed: 270g

  • As part of my periodic LinkedIn doomscrolling (to reach their daily puzzle games I must open the feed) I read an incredibly bad take that using emdashes is a tell-tale sign of the use of artificial intelligence in writing, because obviously nobody uses emdashes. I remember being taught to use them in school, but, unfortunately, I do not remember how. Nonetheless I continue to use them. I hope the inaccuracies are proof enough that, at least for now, my posts are still hand-cranked.

  • Part of joining a new job is learning how the goal-setting and evaluation systems work, and I’ve just about crossed that threshold this week by setting my half-yearly objectives. I’m quite happy with the approach, and the output.

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Soundproofing — Week 5, 2025
item.description: Happy new lunar year! This week in data: 🍣 Time taken to eat Ehomaki: 682.33 seconds ☁️ Average humidity: 27% Had a few delightful catch-ups with people outside my team this week, so I’m feeling like I’m starting to…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Happy new lunar year!

  • This week in data:

    • 🍣 Time taken to eat Ehomaki: 682.33 seconds
    • ☁️ Average humidity: 27%

  • Had a few delightful catch-ups with people outside my team this week, so I’m feeling like I’m starting to settle in better — but there’s still a lot of things for me to learn, as well as some cultural differences to navigate.

  • I don’t normally do this sort of thing, but I’ve been using Endel (a soundscape app, e.g. for concentration, for activity, for sleep, etc.) - and I’m finding it incredibly good. I've used similar apps in the past - this generates music (not AI, dw), instead of playing back pre-recorded tracks, so it feels relatively fresh and non-repetitive. My default soundscape has become Richie Hawtin’s collaboration which I genuinely love. This isn’t a referral-driven recommendation, but I do have a referral code/voucher which nets you a 14-day trial (regularly 7-days).

  • The weather is currently incredibly cold and also incredibly dry which is not doing good things to my skin. To combat it, I went out and bought a humidifier and paired it with my IR hub - so now I have the ability to remotely heat and humidify my flat. It seems to be helping?

    …

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Bangarang — Week 4, 2025
item.description: This week brought the fabled health-check, of Instagram/TikTok/YouTube creator fame. I hate to shatter the illusion† but it turns out to be a series of tests and measures to assess overall health, much like in many…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• This week brought the fabled health-check, of Instagram/TikTok/YouTube creator fame. I hate to shatter the illusion† but it turns out to be a series of tests and measures to assess overall health, much like in many other countries (other than, for some reason, the UK). To all you fellow-watchers of American sitcoms, it’s """a physical""".
  • But the REAL headline of the week is: Monday I showed up bright and early at the Shibaura-konan ward office to finally collect my MyNumber card. The whole process was pretty fast: I had to review some documents, set some passwords and then I walked out with the future of paperwork.
  • Starting to think that Next.JS belongs in the same part of my resume as Magento, IYKWIM.
  • At work we had a new-starter lunch with leadership, which gave the opportunity to submit questions ahead of time. Thinking they would be anonymised, filtered or moderated, I submitted far too many to count. I came to regret this — because on the print-outs I saw that nearly all…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Clicking — Week 3, 2025
item.description: Busy week evenings-wise, but I really needed the social battery recharge it gave me - it’ll really help me lock-in on this whole language-learning thing, as well as my yearly theme. Bank holiday Monday I stayed in doing…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Busy week evenings-wise, but I really needed the social battery recharge it gave me - it’ll really help me lock-in on this whole language-learning thing, as well as my yearly theme.
  • Bank holiday Monday I stayed in doing a few chores including a lot of laundry (first load of the year if you can believe it). Some of the NA team were visiting town so I traded some texts and we met up for a little catch-up and an Okonomiyaki dinner in a Hiroshima themed restaurant. Reminisced about a few things. I’d been meaning to do this in the UK for yonks. Probably my favourite moment of the week - which for this week was a feat.
  • I bought a radio-controlled clock. It also has a feature where it beeps and flashes bright red every few minutes when it thinks that I’m likely to catch a cold. It took me 30 minutes to figure out the pattern, and to figure out how to turn it off. No, that’s it, no other anecdotes here.
  • Tuesday evening, TPC was in town with S so we tore up the izakayas (and their…

Read the full post here...

item.title: Weeknotes: Hauling — Week 2, 2025
item.description: Cleanly breaking weeks with travel seems to work great for me: It creates a neat time-bounded window, or a context if you will. But long-distance travel — which can span days — are a lot fuzzier. These journeys can form…
item.dc:creator: alex
item.content:encoded:
• Cleanly breaking weeks with travel seems to work great for me: It creates a neat time-bounded window, or a context if you will. But long-distance travel — which can span days — are a lot fuzzier. These journeys can form their own chapters.

  • This week in data:

    • Leon wraps consumed: 0
    • Hours slept: Not enough. :(

  • In my case, a chapter involving some extremely pointy elbows and my rib-cage on the the first long leg of my journey back: Being allocated a middle-seat is the opposite of winning the lottery. And it involved some extremely tasty soup (at the pop-up Tin Kee) in Hong-Kong airport which almost made up for everything else...

  • Long-haul flights get the travel out of the way, but, after you’ve done one or two (ever) they aren’t exactly exciting. You learn rules, tricks, optimisations to make the lost time easier to manage. You begin to trade these with your fellow travellers: This route has better food, this seat is easier to sleep in, this airline is much cheaper, this airport is to be avoided at all costs. Long-haul travel becomes a part of the identity - and not one I enjoy embracing.

    …

Read the full post here...
